question: In an activity-driven temporal network with 1000 nodes, where each node activates with a probability of alpha=0.1 and forms m=2 transient connections upon activation, how does the temporal structure of the network influence the spread of an infectious disease modeled using the SIR model with a basic reproduction number R0 = 3, compared to its corresponding time-aggregated static network in which edge weights represent the frequency of interactions over time?
next_plan: Discovery is complete. Key findings from the literature establish that: (1) SIR epidemic spreading on an activity-driven temporal network differs from the aggregated static network, usually resulting in a higher epidemic threshold and a smaller/faster epidemic in the temporal case; (2) Static aggregation tends to artificially inflate outbreak size and duration. Next, I will proceed to the Modeling phase: (a) I will construct two network representations (activity-driven temporal process and the time-aggregated static network from the same activity sequence); (b) I will set up the SIR model on both, matching R0=3; (c) I will determine suitable initial conditions; (d) I will calculate β and γ for both cases and design code for the network and SIR simulation setup; (e) Afterwards, I will run simulations and move into the analysis phase. No simulated data has yet been generated, so the modeling and code design/execution will follow in the next step.
